Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Millimeter-wave communications for real-time sensing, identification, and localization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project are twofold. This technology is characterized by its connection to flexible and hybrid electronics (FHE) technologies and the Internet of Things (IoT), and by its remarkably large potential application space. As an approach that was specifically designed with FHE technologies in mind, this invention has the potential to radically transform the IoT landscape. Indeed, such a combination of capabilities in a thin-film printed form factor could give birth to a new class of ubiquitous IoT devices. The social, economic, and environmental benefits of such devices becoming mainstream and low cost could be significant. This would enable the collection of tracking and sensing data across a large variety of application areas, such as reducing the losses of perishables during transportation of agricultural products, permitting the monitoring of temperature-sensitive health products, and minimizing the risks related to pipeline leaks and aging infrastructure.

This I-Corps project builds on technology that was developed asa low cost Internet of Things (IoT) solution for the ubiquitous and rapid detection of hazardous chemical agents in large industrial and public environments. It was demonstrated for the real-time indoor-light-powered and battery-less detection of ammonia by a low-cost inkjet-printed wireless tag. It consists in the combination of novel communications approaches and radio-frequency hardware which can enable low cost, printed and flexible "Smart-Skin" devices which can communicate and be localized at a maximum range in excess of 1000 yards, while only requiring an operating power on the order of that of a wrist watch. The approach lies at the interface of various current areas of technological progress, such as 5G and IoT networks, flexible and hybrid printed electronics, automotive radars, and nanomaterials-based sensing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The team first started with the hypothesis that warehouse operations managers were suffering from the loss of items in their facilities and that a low-cost wireless tracking solution would be of value to them. Nevertheless, this assumption quickly was proven to be remarkably incorrect: these managers were seldom faced with lost items and the cost of such events was, generally, quite low. This realization led to a pivot towards an industry where the loss items could lead to critically-high losses: aerospace maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO). 
MRO warehouse managers did not suffer either from the loss of parts, but did state the large time requirements of the procedures implemented to prevent these losses as a significant pain point. However, the main pain was in the labeling of the parts, not their tracking. Our technology was unable to address that problem. The team then turned to another industry: container shipping.

The assumption of the team was that the loss of containers would be of great pains to terminal operators' operations managers. After conducting dozens of interviews in the container terminal industry, this assumption was realized to be half accurate. Due to the enormous cost of the loss of a container, costly and redundant procedures are implemented to make these events nearly impossible. Nevertheless, the cost of such procedures is quite well recognized by the IT and operations managers of container terminals. The core of this problem lies in the regular localization errors that punctuate the activities on the terminals. However, the solution could be contingent upon both the terminal operators and the container owner simultaneously agreeing to implement the solution

Upon exploring this industry in more details, the team uncovered a similar but different customer segment that could solve the aforementioned quandary: automated equipment manufacturers. Indeed, automation managers for such companies suffer from the inability to track their equipment with the level of accuracy that is needed for fast-paced automated container handling. Both of these pain points could be addressed using the exclusive wireless technology that Atheraxon, a newly-founded company, is developing during its Phase I NSF SBIR.

The container shipping industry stands as one of the unsung heroes of the modern world which, from its birth in the 1960s cut the cost of shipping goods across the globe by several orders of magnitude, thereby enabling the formation of global supply chains, catalyzing the economic development of emerging nations through the opening of new international markets and lowering the global cost of goods. Nevertheless, this industry has remained largely unmoved by the advent of big data and IoT technologies. We believe that our innovation could empower the general introduction and leveraging of such tools, further lower the costs and increase the accessibility of worldwide shipping, and further benefit the world economy and its weakest members.

If successful, current development efforts conducted by Atheraxon could bring about the emergence of breakthrough energy-autonomous real-time tracking technologies that would significantly increase the efficiency and reduce the costs of worldwide container shipping as well as provide a direct value that could be leveraged to bring about the advent of the smart container and thereby provide enhanced terminal safety and efficiency using rapid, and accurate automation.
